Guys, I got a joystick on amazon, and it is AMAZING! My KSP experience has doubled. YOU NEED ONE!

There is a video on it. Just search KSP joystick setup and you got it!
Yes, I have that Logitech Extreme 3D Pro too. I don't use it for rockets or rovers, but for flying planes it is great. Much easier than the keyboard.
I have tried the Saitek AV8R, but it isn't worth a (lowest level of material). Of course on linux, what am I to suspect?

I have that Logitech Extreme 3D Pro too.

And I use it for rockets and rovers too, it depends on the vehicle and maneuver. A pure roll is easier with buttons.

But I love using my top hat setup for retro translation. Trigger toggles RCS and the thumb button suspends SAS (F key), makes docking MUUCCH easier!

Joysticks are great for KSP! I'm a lefty and I use two sticks at the same time. Translation on my right stick, but for flying rockets and landers usually only use the throttle on that stick, its perfect like that. Plenty buttons for action groups too.

If I recall correctly the options available in KSP only consists of a deadzone and a sensitivity slider which is very crude and basic compared to the flight simulators I am used to. Compare KSP's options to that of an old WWII combat flight simulator, IL-2 Sturmovik 1946.

 

 

In other note, flying with the keyboard in KSP is usually sufficient, although the throttle becomes very handy for landers and skycranes.

What linked one?

 

the word joystick in the post is a link to the on I got

I would say a joystick worth it just for the throttle. It makes landings so much easier horizontally or vertically, since you have so much more control.

That said, I love using the axes while in IVA with RasterProp monitors installed.

In the past I tried using an XBox360 controller, and couldn't do so satisfactorily. Why? Because I like to have access to all three rotation axes, all three translation axes, and the throttle at the same time, rather than switching between them.

While I was able to assign all the controls, the fact that they're in two groups of three, plus one rather than three groups of two, plus one made coordinating maneuvers too difficult for me.

Currently I have a Steam controller, which has nine analog axes (1 stick, 2 touch pads, a pair of throttles, and tilt controls), and there is a special configuration for it, but I'm not playing through Steam now, so I haven't tried it.
